content.webTitle: Public school lobby criticises Labor's 'arbitrary' $250m for Catholic schools

fields.headline: Public school lobby criticises Labor's 'arbitrary' $250m for Catholic schools
fields.bodyText: A public school lobby group has blasted Labor for pledging to restore $250m of funding to Catholic schools, labelling it an arbitrary and partisan move that has astonished parents of public school students. In his March circular the president of the Australian Council of State School Organisations, Phillip Spratt, accused Labor of an “irrational and illogical policy in the scrabble for votes”. The Catholic education office in Melbourne reportedly intervened in the Batman byelection with 30,000 robocalls in favour of Labor’s Ged Kearney, and the federal opposition hopes the sector will continue to lobby for its policy at the 2019 election. On Monday the education minister, Simon Birmingham, inflamed the dispute with the sector, telling Sky News “there’s always somebody who can be bought by a few pieces of silver”, suggesting Labor had bought Catholic Education Melbourne’s support. On Tuesday the Labor frontbench MP Brendan O’Connor labelled the comments – apparently comparing the sector to Judas – “disgraceful” and called on Birmingham to apologise. Labor first promised to restore Catholic school funding in June 2017 as part of its policy to unwind the Coalition’s Gonski 2.0 funding model at a cost of $17bn over 10 years. Given 86% of the projected funding growth cut by the Coalition came from public schools in the first two years, the state system stands to benefit most from Labor’s policy. But restoration of needs-based funding agreements negotiated by the previous Labor governments will include the system-weighted average, a higher of funding per student as a result of averaging family incomes across the Catholic system and some independent systems. Spratt said Bill Shorten’s promise to the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference chairman, Denis Hart, would “arbitrarily” give their schools an extra $250m in the first two years of government, with billions more to come over the next decade. He said Labor should wait until the National School Resourcing Board reviewed socioeconomic status loadings before committing to “special deals”. Spratt compared the promise to George Orwell’s Animal Farm, saying it amounted to a secret rewriting of rules by some that “see themselves as being more equal than others”. “The audacity of this partisan move by the leader of the opposition has astonished many parents, families and staff teams of public schools, as it appears that a small number of Catholic bishops now hold sway over national party politics and policy,” he said. “For the sake of our public schools, its students, staff and families that support them, I hope this Orwellian dystopia remains a work of fiction – there has to be truly needs-based funding in our proud nation with no special deals for entitled want or political opportunism.” The ACSSO is the federal body of parents and citizens associations and says it speaks for the families of 2.5 million children enrolled in public schools. Under the Gonski 2.0 schools funding model, the federal government will provide all government schools with 20% of the school resourcing standard by 2027, while non-government schools will get 80%. In its final form it amounted to a $23.5bn increase in funding over 10 years compared with the 2014 budget, including $6.7bn more for Catholic schools, but a cut compared with Gillard government funding agreements. A spokesman for Shorten said all schools would be better off under Labor because it would “return every dollar that Turnbull has cut”, including for Catholic and government schools. “Under Labor, the neediest schools will get the biggest funding increases, in the shortest time,” he said. “Most of the neediest schools are public schools, so they will get by far the most funding.” On Monday the former prime minister Tony Abbott maintained the rage against his own party’s school funding policy by claiming that Catholic schools would “suffer a big loss in funding”. “If the government was smart, we would have a look at our existing policy,” he told 2GB radio. “It’s going to make low-fee schools in middle class suburbs almost impossible to run.”
